watermark.term: Three circles; the upper one crowned and encircling a cross; in the second circle the letters BM; in the third perhaps the letter S

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in the lower right margin: 1–198. There is an older foliation in ink in the upper right margin of the rectos, which is unreliable (folios 11, 19, 45, 135, and 146 skipped; numbers 78 and 118 not used; two leaves carry the same number 108): 1–194.

p.note: A label for Uppsala University Library and a former shelfmark.

binding.p: Yellowish parchment laced-case binding without boards. Sewn on three supports. Endbands oversewn with hemp cord; endband cores laced through. Gilt edges. Cover extensions and two pairs of alum-tawed ties at foredge. On the foredge one may with difficulty read the binding title ΑΘΑΝΑΣ and a number 3.
The binding is probably of late seventeenth century Spanish origin.
binding.condition: Water damage to top right corner of the first two quires, especially at where the text is erased in that part; worming of the first and last leaf of the volume. The lower corner of has been ripped diagonally, with loss of text.

history.acquisition: Came to Uppsala University Library as part of the Sparwenfeldt donation in .

msItem.title: Vita S. Syncleticae
msItem.rubric: Μηνὶ ἰαννουαρίῳ δʹ· τοῦ ἁγίου Ἀθανασίου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Ἀλεξανδρείας εἰς τὸν βίον τῆς ὁσίας καὶ καλλιπαρθένου Θέκλης
msItem.explicit: ἔπαθλον τῶν ἀγώνων παρ᾽αὐτοῦ δεξαμένη τὴν τῶν οὐρανῶν βασιλείαν ἀμήν.
msItem.note:
The reading of Thecla instead of Syncletica in the rubric is tentative, since most of the ink is abraded. Their confusion could easily have taken place, since, in the beginning of the vita, Syncletica is called a disciple of Thecla and is compared to her. Cf. Castelli (2004)
.

msItem.title: Ad Theodorum Lapsum
Ad Theodorum Lapsum, liber 2
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· πρὸς Θεόδωρον ἀσκητὴν ἐκπεσόντα· πρὸς μετάνοιαν ἐπιστολὴ α´
msItem.explicit: οὐκ ἔτι δεήση φαρμάκων ἑτέρων· τῶ δὲ Θεῶ ἡμῶν ἡ δόξα εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας ἀμήν

msItem.title: Ad Theodorum Lapsum, liber 1
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ· πρὸς Θεόδωρον ἀσκητὴν πρὸς μετάνοιαν λόγος β´
msItem.explicit: πάνυ γὰρ ἡμᾶς εὐφρανεῖς ἐν τούτοις

msItem.note:
The reverse order of texts, where both liber 1 and 2 are copied, is present also in ms Vat. gr. 1628 (11th cent.). Cf. Dumortier (1966)
.

msItem.title: Oraculum
msItem.incipit: Ἐρώτησον ἐν ποίᾳ ἡμέρᾳ κατεκλίθη ὁ ἄρρωστος καὶ ψηφίσαι
msItem.explicit: εἰ μέν εἰσιν ἄνωθεν τοῦ σταυροῦ, ζήσεται, εἰ δὲ κάτωθεν εἰσιν τελευτήσει

note.p: A later inserted note which seems to be a prognostic device on sickness, recovery, and death. It incorporates a picture of the cross and below that an attribution to Leo VI Sapiens Emperor.

A similar text is present in Vat. gr. 915, fol. 47v, and in Vat. gr. 952, fol. 137v; cf. CCAG
.

msItem.title: Hom. 35, Homilia consolatoria
Homilia consolatoria ad aegrotum
msItem.rubric: Λόγος ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασιλείου
msItem.note: The authorship of this text has been disputed, another suggestion being Basilius Caesariensis, or Pseudo-Basil.

msItem.title: Epistula magna (excerptum)
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ παραίνεσις πρὸς τοὺς εἰσαγομένους ἐν κοινοβίῳ· καὶ πρὸς τοὺς ἡγουμένους τῆς ἀδελφότητος
msItem.incipit: Πρῶτον πάντων ὁ τῷ σκοπῷ τῆς εὐσεβείας

note.p: The τοῦ αὐτοῦ in the manuscript title refers to Basilius Caesariensis; cf. CPG 2951, where it is described from this ms as unpublished; Pinakes (Oratio Exhortatoria).

The excerpt corresponds to the following passage in Werner Jaeger’s edition: Jaeger (1954)
.

Our ms is mentioned in Desprez (2006)
, although mistakenly as Upsaliensis graecus 3, and is described as témoin contaminé entre les deux familles anciennes des 150 Képhalaia. Ceux-ci ont pour modèle un exemplaire ancien de la Collection IV, qui n’a pas la lacune du ch. 7 de la Grande Lettre.
Pedro de Valencia used this ms for his Latin translation of the text; see Martín Rodríguez (2002)

msItem.title: Confessio Fidei
msItem.incipit: Πιστεύω εἰς ἕνα Θεὸν πατέρα παντοκράτορα
msItem.explicit: τῶν κατὰ τὴν προκειμένην ὁμολογίαν πιστευόντων καὶ φοβουμένων τὸν Θεὸν ἀμήν

note.p: This text is written on an inserted leaf, probably as a companion piece to Basil’s letter to the Emperor on , above. The verso page, , is blank.

msItem.title: Ascetica quaedam
msItem.rubric: Περὶ τοῦ γέροντος τοῦ πρὸς τῇ ἐξόδῳ αὐτοῦ ἀπολέσθαι κινδυνεύσαντος
msItem.incipit: Ποτὲ τίς γέρων ἔμενεν μετὰ εὐλαβοὺς ἀδελφοῦ μοναχοῦ ἱκανὰ ἔτη προβεβηκὸς
msItem.explicit: ἐγένετο μετὰ ψαλμῶν καὶ εὐχῶν κατὰ τὸ ἔθος ἡ τάφη τοῦ γέροντος

note.p: This text is unidentified so far. A transcription is in press and will also be included in the Lund monastic database (http://monastica.ht.lu.se/monastica.php).

On a later inserted note on coins and their values: Ἰστέον ὅτι τὰ λεπτὰ καλοῦνται ἀσσάρια, ἤγουν τὰ νουμμία ἑξήκοντα ἀσσαρίων ὑπήρχε τὸ δεινάριον· ἕκατον δειναρίων ὑπήρχε ὁ ἄργυρος καὶ πέπραται ὁ κύριος δὲ εἰς λʹ ἀργυρίων, ἅτινα συνάγονται ͵Γ δεινάρια, γινόμενα χρυσοῦ δὲ νουμμία ρʹ. For a similar passage, cf. Nicolaus Catascepenus, Vita sancti Cyrilli Phileotae 37, 7. Above the note a name (difficult to read) μακαρίου φιλοσόφου.

collation.p: After there are two stubs of fine parchment. is an independent leaf, a makeshift insertion tacked in with the help of a couple of knots. The last two leaves in the volume are pasted to the preceding quaternion.
collation.signatures: Generally in the upper right margin of first recto and the lower right margin of last verso, beginning with βʹ on and ending with κδʹ on . Some of the signatures, especially on recto pages, have been trimmed out. The signatures are marked by a short horizontal stroke above the letter, and appear to be written in the same colour as the ink of the text.

handDesc.handNote: This expert and consistent hand writes a Perlschrift of small modules and fast ductus, typical of the monastic production of the late tenth or early eleventh century. The oblique strokes of Kappas, Chis and Lambdas produce an angular effect and impress a movement to the right, though the letters are not themselves visibly slanted. The vertical stroke of Kappa has a small hook when the letter is enlarged in the margin. Although the writing is relaxed, no excesses are present.
A later addition on a separately inserted leaf. The hand is, according to Stig Yngve Rudberg, datable to the fourteenth cetury.

decoDesc.p: Rubrics are written in brown ink but written over with red ink, forming a kind of characteristic halo (similar to yellow spalmature in Southern Italian mss). Subtitles (or other division headings) are numerous. Simple dividers, such as a dot-filled line, sometimes combined with crosses, further mark the text divisions. Initials are simple enlarged majuscules, sometimes in red.

history.origin:
Written in the late 10th c. in a monastic setting. Stig Yngve Rudberg proposes Constantinople as place of origin ( Rudberg (1952)
).
